conclusion: Four identical wooden blocks (A, B, C, D) are on a smooth horizontal surface, blocks B and C are connected by a spring, and a force F is applied to block B.
All blocks accelerate together with the same acceleration a.
The surface is smooth (no friction with the surface).
We need to find the static friction force on block D.

premise: All blocks accelerate together with the same acceleration a.
conclusion: Blocks C and D must remain in contact, and blocks A and B must remain in contact.
Block B has forces acting: F (pulling force), spring force (to the left), and possibly contact force from block A.

premise: Block B has forces acting: F (pulling force), spring force (to the left), and possibly contact force from block A.
conclusion: Equation for block B: F - F_spring = m·a.
Block C has forces acting: F_spring (to the right), and static friction from block D.

premise: Block C has forces acting: F_spring (to the right), and static friction from block D.
conclusion: Equation for block C: F_spring - F_frictionDC = m·a.
Block D has forces acting: Static friction from block C.

premise: Block D has forces acting: Static friction from block C.
conclusion: Equation for block D: F_frictionDC = m·a.
Block A has forces acting: Contact force from block B.

premise: Block A has forces acting: Contact force from block B.
conclusion: Equation for block A: F_contactBA = m·a.

premise: The total external force on the system is F, and the total mass is 4m.
Equation for block D: F_frictionDC = m·a and a = F/(4m).

conclusion: The static friction force acting on block D is F/4.
